I've always hated the platitude that the only thing giving things meaning is that it ends, including life. It's not a perspective I'm able to process as it seems like a complete non-sequester fabricated by people in denial about what death and non-existence are, and seeking to make it more romantic.

Things have value because it incites a feeling of some kind (in yourself or others,) be it sating curiosity, deriving fulfillment, or simply experiencing non-descript joy. To me that has nothing to do with time or timing. I do things because I want and can experience them, not because I might not tomorrow. Yes, you could do that thing in two-hundred years, but why would you? It's interesting and fun now.. That's all you should need as motivator.

Should things no longer incite those feelings, and become a dull monotone, then sure, that's the point where living no longer makes sense. But I could live a thousand lifetimes and always have something (new) to learn or do on this planet alone, let alone the galaxy, let alone the universe. I don't foresee ever wanting to die out of a sense of being 'done,' it's simply a horrific inconvenience I have to make my peace with.

I really think you missed the most important point. Evolution in the future.

Let's imagine humanity goes the path of prolongating life. More people live longer - more competition for resourses with a younger generation. That would mean new generations appear more seldom. But the frequency of generations is what defines the spread of genes. Less frequency - less chances for a needed gene combination to appear, spread and prevent sudden extinction.

Some illnesses or cataclysms in the future could potentially kill the whole population faster, than humanity finds appropriate cure or solution to a sudden problem. But with variability and high frequency of generations the chance of at least some part of population forming a resistivity or immunity increases.


Prolongation of life is increasing vulnerability of species. All evolution simulations show that high-frequency species are more stable. Humanity with global high life expectancy would not be able to compete, for example, with extraterrestrial highly adaptable life forms.

And it is not just about immunity. More unique people born - more ideas and inventions come with them. Even those people, who think that all problems will be solved by science and research, should admit, that they would need that variability and renovations of humans for high intensity of inventions.

This is actually the first video by Michael that has disappointed me. It feels very one sided and sensational, rather than a meaningful discussion about death. Of course we should accept that immortality isn't realistic, but we should also strive to give people the longest and healthiest lives possible. Accepting our current life expectancy isn't helpful when we have the possibility to give people more life. The discussion of death should not be "death is beautiful" Vs "cryogenics". Death is not beautiful and cryogenics is the most extreme opposition. The real discussion should be "death is horrible and aging is the biggest cause of death, how can we prevent aging and allow people to live longer, more fulfilling lives?".

I’m torn. I agree with the idea death = life is more valuable. Scarcity creates value that’s a fundamental principle of reality. But I also think, wether we achieve immortality or even increasing lifespan by a mere order of magnitude (still a blip in the wind in the cosmos of time), say technology comes along this century to allow us to live 700-1200 years instead of 70-120 yrs.

As far as our evolutionary programming is concerned, a “mere” 10x in life expectancy might as well be immortality, I don’t think a person alive today nor anyone for potentially hundreds of years from now, would even have the mental tools to construct a perspective to truly comprehend and appreciate how absolutely mind blowing it would be knowing “X new technology now can prove with mathematical certainty that I am statistically more likely to die at 1000 years of age, than the likelihood of me dying at 100 yrs old”

People would probably spend the next 10 years of life getting sidetracked every situation of normal life, to attempt to comprehend what this even means lol

Never mind achieving full immortality. We might need the next 1000 years to fully grasp that concept. 😂

But what I meant to get at, is A) I don’t think we need immortality to feel effectively immortal, guarantee most people would act as such with just a 1k Yr lifespan, for a century or two anyway haha

And point B) to expand, I also agree life would gain value, or maybe meaning is a better word. Because after a short period of contemplation, maybe a few years of hedonism in the case of certain types of people, I’m pretty sure I’d just end up (in “relatively” short order) getting ridiculously excited that instead of stressing TF out and overthinking way too much because life is short and I have to always question if there’s not a better plan I could implement to achieve what I want and spend my short life doing what an imperfect, fallible, and by future standards monumentally stupid person like me has deteriorated to be the most meaningful path....

.... and throw it out the window, all the stress, anxiety, all the plans, because now I get to plan what would basically be TEN LIFETIMES! I would have the dopamine level of a crackhead figuring out all the rad shit I could plan and then run like the wind into the start of my thousand year conquest of epic proportions 😂 I’d be too excited to “be lazy because I have so much time now that I’m not constrained to a short time in life I have no need to do anything it can all be done later” ...

That’s the usual argument ppl say, and I think those are either just lazy ppl or they didn’t think it through much

Because I can say with near certainty even if I got a guarantee of doubling my lifespan I would immediately live with immensely lower levels of stress, anxiety, depression, overthinking and everything else that’s a product of not enough time

I’d Just be super present and excited in everything I did I feel like

And that’s the end of my novel length rant 😂😂😂😂

16:10 here, on the flip side, I think death might take away passion and drive. If you and the people you love will eventually die, then why bother with anything? The only acceptable answer I can come up with is, doing something is may be better that nothing. At least you won't be bored. And if you do do something, you might as well do something you're interested in, hence passion and all the other drives sneak back in the conversation.

In that same token, when you're sufficiently comfortable in life, and you're privileged to analyze these existential questions, you might get depressed because nobody has the answers and everyone is explaining merely to comfort their brain or have faith of some kind, heck there's a whole mortician career choice lmao (slightly similar to the consulting endeavor a priest or an imam would do for your spiritual questions).

Again on the contrary, if one is in any life threatening situation (sickness, war...) all this discussion wouldn't matter. One would quickly long for a single peaceful moment. Life becomes precious. Atheists become believers.

These cycle of existential queries anchored to the question "What happens after death?" always linger deep under whatever we do (consciously or subconsciously). But somehow and somewhat contradictorily, we try not to think about death and are willfully blind to it.

I like the ladies perspective but there is one thing she said I do disagree with. She said that the idea of people living to the point of immortality is not a sensible position to take. That's not how evolution works, if we as a species are able to advance to the point of medical achievements that allows us to be immortal, it's not an overnight process. It is an opportunity for the species to progress and learn more things. Her first reasoning was it not being environmentally sensible, that's an indirect effect. If we progress in the way evolution guides us towards than we may find other solutions to food or social developments that allow us to be immortal and not effect the environment. To be honest I think the opposite of what she said would happen, if we found a way to become immortal than people may start caring more about the future of the planet and take better care of things. A lot of the negligence that happens today is because people in charge have the mentality of "I wont be around for that". Becoming immortal would propel us to want to find better food alternatives and ways to impact the environment less.

I cannot accept the reasoning. The natural state is to die. A person doesn't live by default. They have to actively attempt to keep themselves alive. Eating, drinking, preparing, etc. To accept death because of old age or some disease is to accept death because you stopped eating. You gave up the fight. I get a sense of "romance" being attributed to a "natural" death. Philosophically, all death is natural. Be it old age, disease, murder, or an accident. I'm pretty sure we can agree that reducing murders and accidents are good, then we must also accept that reducing old age or disease related deaths are also good.

But I do agree with the sentiment that accepting one's mortality is important.

10:31 Here's two great examples of how science research goes wrong:

1) Faced with no evidence of the effect, Michael says "it just makes me hungry to do more research." Research that doesn't show anything interesting doesn't get published. Due to the law of averages, after repeated attempts eventually a study will show a connection that doesn't actually exist. That's the study that gets published. If the study doesn't show what you want, keep trying and eventually it will.

2) The hypothesis of the study was not that the death-aware group would spend more time deliberating. To find this correlation after-the-fact is called "p-hacking". There are millions of qualities that could be different between the two groups by chance. Searching for a correlation among the millions of possible correlations will inevitably turn up something, but it won't be a real connection.

For more on these issues see Vertiasium's video on the reproducibility crisis: "Is Most Published Research Wrong?"

There’s an uncontrolled variable here, being how harsh the punishment seems to each participant. Someone might not think 10 years is all that harsh for a certain crime. I think you’d have better results if you didn’t explicitly state how long 1 versus 7 was in terms of punishment and just left that up to the participants imagination. That way you’re just getting an untarnished answer to the question “How harshly do you think they should be punished?” People would be less likely to max out the scale that way unless they really meant it and had the emotional driver you’re testing involved.

After we die, the Bible says we’ll face God as our Judge. Have you ever rebelled (sinned) against God? Examine yourself by God’s Law, the Ten Commandments. Have you ever told a lie? Ever stolen (the value is irrelevant)? Jesus said, “Whoever looks at a woman to lust for her has already committed adultery with her in his heart.” In God’s courtroom, our sins are very serious crimes. They’re so evil that the just punishment is death and eternity in a terrible place called Hell.

The Bible says that God takes no pleasure in the death of the wicked. He is rich in mercy and provided a Savior: “God so loved the world that He gave His only begotten Son, that whoever believes in Him should not perish but have everlasting life.” Jesus Christ died on the cross, paying the death penalty for sinners. He then rose from the dead three days later, defeating death. Hundreds saw Him after His resurrection; it’s no fairy tale. Jesus fulfilled all the prophecies about the promised Savior, written in the Holy Scriptures hundreds of years before His birth.

Religious rites, sacred traditions, or attending church can’t save you. Salvation is a free gift of God that you can’t earn. To know God and have your sins forgiven, do what the Bible says: repent and believe. Trust in Jesus as you’d trust in a parachute—don’t just “believe” it can save you, put it on and cling to it with all of your being. Wholeheartedly commit yourself to following Christ, and turn your back on sin. Then show your gratitude by obeying His command to be baptized. Be sure to also join a Christian church and read the Bible daily. God will never let you down.

"I want to give my atoms and molecules BACK to the universe"

is so elegantly put, because regardless of whether or not we choose, that's the process that happens, and from Michael's perspective, he finds it better to say that it is a choice at the point of death, rather than an inevitability.

Then when he says 'BACK to the universe,' it can be implied that he took from the universe in the first place, but that's a difference that lies in perspective. We all take from those around us, specifically our caretakers' food and shelter when we're children, all without our consent, but that doesn't necessarily mean we are taking from them. Yes, the food we consume to grow is the food they are not consuming to survive (under a finite food assumption) but they are willingly giving it to us. No human in history has willingly consented to being conceived, but when we are, we're comprised of material that would be elsewhere, and our consent keeps getting pushed back further and further as we grow older. For example, it's irresponsible to not feed a child under your care, regardless of their consent to accept food from you, because as a consequence, they would die. But say a 30 year-old that is equally unable to provide for themselves and relies on the generosity of others as a means of survival, doesn't want to die or starve if they do not consent to being provided for, although it's inextricably linked. It does however show the acknowledgement of displaced time and food from these caregivers, and empathetically saying "don't waste your time on me." Even though from the perspective of the caregiver, "They are worth it because they are here."

Michael isn't saying that because the atoms that he's made from came from somewhere, that they were taken, but rather that regardless of his consent, it was given. We feel the need to justify our existence many times under different circumstances, but in the context of death, it can be comforting to know that we were here, and that's justification enough. That our ability to make choices and how those choices affect others don't have to matter in order to know, that because we are going to die, we had to have lived, and because we lived, someone cared enough for us to.

This probably falls into a coping/denial cultural belief, but considering the line drawn between fact and unknowable, I think this belief is the most optimistic and conducive to positive behavior, taking into account all collective human knowledge. If evolution is how we were brought about, an uncountable amount of organisms had to live, die, duplicate, and become extinct for everything alive to be here, including us, serves as a testament to all, even those that have yet to live.

The universe don't care about your life or death, but because the earth and it's fruits were born of the universes circumstance, it at least cares enough to give you life, even for a lil.
When you die, you don't HAVE to matter, have meaning, leave legacy, or progress, you had to be there.

Michael asked at the beginning, "How long is too long?" in regard to length of life. Well, I'll tell you how long too long is: When all those that you know and love are all passed away. All of your immediate family, aunts, uncles, first cousins, and your friends. I am the very youngest of a really large family. My mother is the youngest of ten children and I am the youngest of her and my father's five children. So I am the bottom of the barrel. ALL but two of my MANY aunts and uncles have passed away. Autoimmune disease runs in my family so I have had many cousins suddenly die from those diseases. Also, several of them have grown old and died of natural causes. So I only have a few left. So out of my huge family, there are very few left that are still alive and the loss of so many relatives has been VERY difficult.

Then, my wife suddenly died a few years ago and that was devastating. The feeling of aloneness starts to really bother you when it gets down to only a few relatives and friends being left in your life. At some point when they are all gone it will be almost unbearable. So, how long is too long to live? To the point of being all alone after everyone else has passed on because you outlived them. Just watch the show from the 90s called Highlander. It is so heartbreaking at times because the main character is immortal and travels throughout Scotland and Ireland, so sometimes he sees old castle ruins and he will remember living there with a wife and children. Then that memory will turn to the death of his wife and children when they grow old and die. He has been married and had children many times because of how long he has lived. It is a very good show and demonstrates how having incredible longevity is actually like a curse in some respects. Too long life is when we are left all alone to struggle with the emotional devastation of losing everyone dear to you.

I had a girlfriend, she started dating other guys. My girlfriend wanted to live some other life without me in it, so I said, "Okay, I want the best for you and I want you to pursue your happiness." My lady friend and I drank alcohol about it, and she gave me the same advice I gave her when she was in that position and I became okay with the breakup immediately. But we were really drunk, so she spent the night in my apartment. I only have one bed, so you know what that means: She took the bed and I slept on the couch. But on the couch, I really can't sleep. I approached the bed, gently sat on it and I reached for her shoulder to pull her closer to me. She stirred and woke up. She asked what's up. I told her, "you know, the first time I saw you, I was watching a video and left it playing to get myself a sandwich then went to the store to get some mayo then I got so distracted by life that I forgot to finish the video." This is very interesting because it says show much about Michael's worldview. The fact that he said "I want to give my atoms and molecules BACK to the universe" implies that by his very existence, he has TAKEN from the universe.

The lady she is speaking to also mirrors this and reinforces it. This is such a sad way to view oneself and humanity because it stems from academic institutions that view humanity as a virus to the Earth and that the environment would be better off without humanity.

However, at the same time, they acknowledge that the universe CREATED humanity, through this incredible process of evolution and natural selection.

The universe gave birth to humanity and every atom and molecule within us will forever be OF the universe.

As far as the environment, humanity is making enormous progress in reducing pollution and reducing carbon emissions but what is never explained is that human activity, including agriculture, only accounts for 1/3rd of all global carbon emissions and carbon emissions, as a whole, only account 6% of all greenhouse gases.

This means human activity only accounts for 2% of all greenhouses gases. Thus, if man were to go extinct, 98% of all greenhouses gases will remain which completely disproves this morbid view that we, solely by our very existence, are evil, a plague to the environment, the world, and somehow the universe thereby grossly overestimating our negative influence on all three whole often ignoring the positive influence that will eventually far outweigh the negative

Also, agriculture actually fertilizes and enriches the land, and those benefits last for decades which is why birds prefer and migrate to farmland.

I love Life, I love Music, I love Learning, I love My Children, My mom, My Wife, My Grandmother (Still Alive) My Aunt Who’s Living with Stage 4 Breast Cancer and All of My friends and Family. I think "you don't want to live forever, because you will eventually experience everything that there is to experience and then what?" people forget an important factor: there are new forms of entertainment being created continuously. Two decades ago we didn't have VR (okay, commercially viable VR). More than half a century ago we didn't have video games (or even computers). Century ago? No TV. Two centuries ago? No radio or movies either.

Not to mention that there are constantly made new pieces of entertainment in existing forms of entertainment. New books, new movies, new plays, new games, etc.

Point being, you will seldom "run out" of things to experience because there's going to always be something new to experience, for as long as the civilization goes on.

And if you would be fully immortal and impervious to any damage or able to regenerate your body (instead of boring immortality, where you can l8ve forever, you won't age or get sick, but will still die if your body is damaged too much), there are things to experience that normally you couldn't because they'd be fatal for you, such as how it is to swim in an active volcano during a huge eruption or making a party in an operational nuclear reactor.

To answer your question Michael, no.

To me aging feels a lot more bitter than dying, given that I wouldn't have unconcluded businesses that would concern me too much at the time of death. (E.g. if I die before my parents do I'd feel very sad)

I'd like to think death as more of the sexy part of my life cycle. To have my soul/life force swiftly drawn out of my body by a powerful unknown force is exciting. If there is an afterlife unimaginable from whence you lived, it would excite me to experience that; if there isn't, the eternal slumber that'll take away all my concerns and tiredness doesn't sound like a bad deal either.

Aging however terrifies me. To slowly lose physical attraction, to slowly lose interest and passion of anything that I once enjoyed, to slowly lose the athleticism I spent years to build up, and to slowly lose faculty I mean it's just cruel. You can't even spot these changes in real time as it happens, and once the realization strikes you it'd be already too late.

I'd rather die young, should situations permit.

And even the most narcissistic of Historical figures have cared more about people remembering their legacy than how their legacy ended. Humans have natural tendencies to be a Altruistic and Self Sacrificial, and it has played an important part of human evolution and survival. The gospel is that Jesus the son of God, came as a man, being fully God and fully man, lived a sinless perfect life, and gave his life as a random for all of mankind by paying and taking on the punishment of our sins by dying for our sins on the cross. And on that cross he bore the sins of all of mankind upon himself, caring a heavy burden that you and I couldn’t bare. So, after his death, 3 days later, he victoriously rose form the dead. So, you must truly believe that and truly put your faith in him.


Along with believing the gospel comes repentance. Repentance means to have a change of mind, so you must have a change of mind concerning your current state of being, meaning, that you must turn from your sins and turn to God in faith. Having a realization that you are a sinner, and are in need of a savior. Jesus came to save you. To save you from the path of destruction, which is the lifestyle of a sinner, which ultimately leads a person to hell. Sin leads to hell. The Bible says that the wages of sin is death, meaning, that the result or consequence of sin is death. When Adam sinned, death was brought into the world. And now all men must die. But…. as the verse continues to read ,it says that the gift🎁 of God is eternal life through Christ Jesus-Romans 6:23. So, his gift towards you is eternal life…. after death. Life truly begins after death. Life after death is eternal… so whatever place you end up in, you will be there for eternity, which is why this message is sooo very important. You eternity is at stake! Lastly, I will conclude with this famous Bible verse that you mighty or might have not heard of. Yet, it is the essential message of the gospel itself!


John 3:26- For God so loved the world, that he gave his only begotten Son, that whosoever believeth in him should not perish,( Die as a sinner and end up in hell) but have ever lasting life.



To summarize all of this up, the core message is that, Christ came to redeem, to recuse, to atone, and that by having faith in him, and his testimony, which is the gospel, and turning to him in repentance, you as a individual will be saved, and through Christ, you may have access to eternal life.

To redeem and to recuse you from your own folly, which is your sinfulness, your sins, which will lead you to eternal damnation, which is hell.

That through him by putting your faith and trust in him, and believing the gospel as truth, and turning to him in repentance, then you may have access to eternal life. It is a gift🎁 from God to a true believer.

The thing that really bugs me about trying to overcome aging is that if enough people become immune to it--and we all know which ones will, the super rich, the politicians, the oligarchs--then the world order has lost one of the very most reliable promises we have that it will evolve.  The CEO of that cryo place wants to believe that people will grow wiser as they age, but I'm not so optimistic.  You can now already note plenty of elderly people who stopped personally growing, widening their horizons and evolving since their teens or twenties, although plenty still do grow wiser.  I think however that it is going to be the non evolving type of person who clings to life the strongest, and that will be salient among those who cease to age.  And furthermore, if aging is cured among all or most people, this will literally stall evolution itself, of the biological variety.  It won't fully stop, because people won't be invincible, nor infertile (but an immortal human race may mandate sterilization, possibly for all but the privileged families and clans) but the whole process of evolution in humans will slow to a molasses pace because individuals couldn't cope with finitude.

"Плохо что человек смертен, но ещё хуже что человек внезапно смертен" ("Мастер и Маргарита"). Лично я общаюсь с людьми которым более 70 и 80 лет и по моим субъективным наблюдениям правильное восприятие смерти у человека начинает появлятся только после 85-90 лет, человеку становится "тяжело носить своё тело". И мне, как наблюдателю заметно ухудшение умственных способностей которое начинается после 85 лет. Я слышал что ресурс человеского тела расчитан на 120 лет, и как видно из новостей некоторым удаётся доживать до такого возраста. Моё мнение что не стоит мечтать о безсмертии или о небывалом долголетии, к примеру в 500 лет. Человеку стоит жить 120 лет, ну или хотя бы дотянуть до 90 и этого вполне достачно. Поверте если Вам будет 90 лет Вы уже не захотите безсмертия, Вы будете хотеть чтобы всё это поскорее закончилось. Насчёт замораживания после смерти, не вводите себя в заблуждение, это всего лишь мумификация, очень хорошая, но мумификация. И если кому-то очется себя заморозить, то объязательно нужно замораживать всё тело, а не тольго голову, и кстати что они делаю с кровью, они её что просто выбрасывают, если это так то это глупо. Пусть слитая кровь и будет повреждена при заморозке, но зато она сохранится. Да, хранение всего тела куда дороже чем одной только головы, и многим хочется экономить на смерти, но оно того не стоит, поскольку нейронная система это не только мозг но вся сеть нейронов, доходящая до кончиков пальцев. Сознание человека не только в его голове, но и частично в спинном мозге тоже (я имею ввиду систему рефлексов), и это важно помнить для тех кто хочет "воскреснуть после заморозки". Лично по мне, хранение только головы в заморозке, это всего лишь рановидность фетиша на декапитацию. С другой стороны люди ещё 8000 лет назад оставляли после смерти близких только их черепа, после чего облепляли эти черпа глиной и рисовали на нём подобие лица, и потом хранили эти головы из глины с черепом внутри у себя дома. Если всё же денег не хватает на свою смерть ограничтесь кладбищем и деревом возле могилы, если и на это денег нет, ну... тогда вы прожили не очень хорошую жизнь. И кстати, есть кое что страшнее своей смерти, это смерть всей семьи, а ещё ужаснее смерть всего рода. С другой стороны, по заверениям палеогенетики, где-то 70000 лет назад мы все произошли от одного мужчины, а 100000 лет назад от одной женщины.

People don’t take risks in life thinking that it’s because they’ll die someday, it’s because it gives us a sense of fulfillment and satisfaction. Death robs us from ever feeling that again, and I’d much rather be in control of how long I get to live for. Yeah, true immortality is statistically improbable, but defeating aging and extending our lifespans actually allows us to take our time to make sure we do things right. We would no longer feel pressured into making hasty life decisions that will affect us for the rest of our lives. Defeating aging is a good thing!

Not being able to die is a horrible thought. We've been fed this idea via folklore, entertainment and forms of media that becoming immortal by default means that one simply ceases to age (cells cease to die), and/or that one would be in absolutely optimal physical, mental and emotional health forever. How would human mind cope with a thoudand years worth of wars, natural catastrophes, witnessing millions upon millions of killings, murders, deaths, acts of abuse, you name it?

Imagine aging as per normal and being aware of not being able to die, ever. Imagine suffering from a severe treatment-resistant depression and being aware of not being able to die, ever. Imagine having MS, dementia, or some horrible illness causing constant unbearable pain and being aware of not being able to die ever. Imagine being wrongfully sentenced for life in prison and being aware of not being able to die, ever.

Let that sink in while daydreaming of immortality. ;)

I feel like for the experiment at 8:00 it would be interesting to test the same participants twice, to see if people get more or less lenient compared to their own standard, and not the average of a group. Because the individuals in the randomized group might still all show the same behaviour (maybe everyone in the group gets less lenient for example), but their values amongst each other might still be divided.
So if situation A has person 1 give a #1 and person 2 a #7, yet situation B person 1 gives a #7 and person 2 gives a #1, they might still exhibit that they get less lenient about punishing this person, but because of the different values in the group ot will still give the same average as a more lenient control group....

Death is a pretty interesting topic... I do believe that death does give some sort of meaning to our lives, or else no one would really be special because we could just live all the experiences we could’ve ever wanted. But at the same time... 100 years (which is what I think the average lifespan of humanity today) isn’t really that long. Well, yeah, it is, but about 10% of the time you will be in school. And then probably 45% of that time doing work. And then the rest is just retirement. I think it’s best if we can make it so that we live longer and have longer youth, meaning that at age, like, 150 or something you won’t just be a helpless, skinny bag of bones and organs bound to a wheelchair. I honestly would love to extend my life and youth, because there’s so much that I’d love to do but I’m not sure if my natural lifespan will be enough. I would love to see the future, and be able to live in the vacation home of my dreams... on Mars. Or stay around long enough to witness a pollution and climate changing free society. Or even experience a completely virtual reality game without the struggle of wearing a headset and all that stuff.

6:45 "The point is to prime their mortality salience"

Question 1 at the 4:00 minute mark. I have some questions. Was the money recovered or is it gone? That to me seems like it should be factored in, no?
If the charity or whatever was made whole...or is the charity out $1M? That plays a part. Should he be punished for stealing? Absolutely . Should he be punished differently if the charity got the $1M back vs the charity being out the $1M? Absolutely....right?

It is what happens most commonly...but I really don't like leaving people up to their own devices to come to conclusions. This person is taking their life experiences into account...and this one is taking theirs. There is a TON of stuff that SHOULD be factored in...or at least offered at least pondered whether to be taken into consideration.
I get it...this show is not about going into depth and details necessarily. I'm just saying what popped into my head as I watch this. I try to put myself into the shoes of the people ranking and trying to think how I would respond. I feel like Gareth in The Office BBC trying to figure out the best way to get the grain, fox and rabbit(?) across the river. Few questions.

3 minutes in and I'm getting a sense of PRE-Suasion. Suggesting and putting things into peoples' minds BEFORE they make a decision, changes their decisions. What they focus on...what they factor into their decision making progress.
Left alone, people bring to the party whatever they want. Give them subtle hits or directly tell them...bring this. Think of this. And doggone it...more likely people will.

Search Pre-Suasion, Robert Cialdini. Good good stuff

Personally, I've lived around death since childhood due to my mother working at a florist as a designer and obviously funerals are a part of everyday "business". I'm asked about one subject in particular and two questions pop up more than any others "don't you have a problem around dead people?" and "doesn't it bother you to be near death?". Honestly you do get used to bodies (for example i'm 36 and i've been to thousands of visitation prior to the families arrival) it does help i'm sure that i arrive after the mortician and coroner have done their work. However that visage of a gentleman or lady lying in that casket has matured my perception of death to the point that though I obviously don't want to die I also don't feel that I alone have a choice in the matter of the end of life. To me death is not only universal, it's necessary. I understand why I get flak for this position because it's not normal yet I feel that life being temporary spurs grow and a certain drive you simply wouldn't have with a lifespan of a 1000 years for example at the same time it will become apparent in the future that our natural lifespans will not be able to accommodate the amount of information needed to further studies of ever increasing complexity. So in conclusion, I believe it is necessary for humans to live longer if for no other reason than to accumulate more knowledge and to further our species progression but at the same time knowing there's an end to your story I feel drives that progression more than hampering it. Death is the end of 1 and the beginning of another so my only message to those out there reading this is, Don't fear death even mighty stars and born then eventually die if you look outward or inward all around you death gave way to life and vise versa, living would have no real purpose if you had nothing to achieve over a given time and knowing you have a limited window to achieve that task or goal in gives you that push to keep going if for nothing else than to be remembered by those actions. “The gods envy us. They envy us because we’re mortal, because any moment may be our last. Everything is more beautiful because we’re doomed. You will never be lovelier than you are now. We will never be here again.” - Troy, Achilles.

Funny how people often ask what is death? The truth is simple. Death is the opposite of life. While alive you are a living being - to use a Bible word you are a soul. The use of that word (soul) is unfortunate because so often people will add “immortal”. But the word in scripture never implies immortal. It is correctly translated as “being”. Check Strongs Concordance for proof. So man was created a living being (soul) and is subject to death. The soul (being) that sinneth it shall die. - ezek 18:20. In that verse it refers to what is the second death and not dying here and now. Remember the word resurrection? After dying there is a resurrection from the dead. If we had an immortal soul floating around playing a harp we would sure hate being resurrected as a human soul (being) again. I know I would hate that anyhow.

So now if ever someone tells you you have an immortal soul you ask where that soul is? Then ask where in the Bible are the words “immortal soul”?

If people knew they would live for thousands of years I betcha they would be better stewards of this world we live on. The problem is, and always has been, that we all know we will die soon. Even 80 years or so is way too soon. People are just gaining some semblance of wisdom when they reach that age.
But the fact that we know we only have so many years to live turns many people greedy for more, more of everything, the good life. Fast cars, a nice home, refrigerator always stocked with plenty of food, lots of money, a beautiful spouse. The fact is, there is nothing wrong with wanting or having these things, it's how we go about getting them. It's about sustainability. When you have a planet with limited space and resources, an environment that can only handle so much manipulation. If everybody wants fish for dinner so many days a week, and over fishing the results, there will be consequences, and major problems down the road. Same as everyone wanting and driving cars. If you know your going to die, many people just don't care about such words as sustainability, environmental, overpopulation.
I'm thinking that that would not be the case if people were super long lived.
They would think and feel differently about those dirty words and not just give them lip service. The world would change dramatically.
So I'm all in where it concerns immortality.

Caitlin the death proponent is wrong isn't she? If life is more precious the shorter it is, mandatory suicide might be the best idea ever, hospitals would probably be a waste of money and the terminally ill could be expected to be the happiest. The whole "scarcity brings value" argument is only valid for some resources and the line of reasoning is uncomfortably similar to the antinatalist one.

I believe that way of thinking is nothing but another way to dress up our fatalism in fancier clothes. Stoicism, acceptance, defeatism, whatever you want to call it, accepting what one can't change is good for you. Accepting death, just like accepting you can't change the past even if you regret some parts. All good.

But this doesn't mean we have to be aware of our death to feel passion or enjoy learning. It's simply a non-sequitur. Young people tend to be passionate and they also tend to NOT think about death as something imminent. All this deathy-death sophistry makes me want to kill myself. If you know what I mean.

My grandparents are in their 80s. One conversation we have had recently is how sad they feel that all the people they have known their age or older are all pretty much dead. They mention that it is hard to find anyone in our small town who can relate to their experiences from 50 plus years ago. They explain basically that they can tell me about all kinds of things about my town from the 1940s and 1950s. I may seem very interested, but considering I was born in the 1970s I will never be able to experience the same emotional connections to various places or events on the same level as them because I was not alive to experience it like they did.  If these patients can managed to be brought back to life would they still have their memories of their previous lives in the 20th and 21st centuries? What would the emotional effects be on someone who wakes up to realize they are alive again and it is the 22nd or 23rd centuries? Here you are, in your body right now. How did you get here? Why are you conscious of your own existence? What is the meaning of it all? Well, logically speaking, you exist, meaning the atoms in your brain which had existed in the earth once before are inside of you. Your existence began when you were born, but the atoms that form you have been here since the universe had begun. After you die, (if we are to believe what is currently scientifically known), your consciousness and yourself cease to exist. Your body and all that remains are taken by the earth. Consumed by organisms, becoming part of the earth. But you had been born before, from seemingly nothing, trapped inside this flesh cage, controlling your own body, aware of your own existence. You were born. So, what does that mean for you after you die? In truth, nobody can know for certain unless they were to die themselves, and if that were the case, they wouldn’t be here telling you about it. But since you have come from another organism, and you are in your body right now, it might not be wrong to think that you may live again in another form. The atoms and molecules that make up your body will be eaten by the worms and absorbed by the plants. Your body will be used by nature. Your brain will be consumed as well. You will be apart of life flourishing, and this life will use some of those molecules and atoms to reproduce. Will you be apart of those new organisms? Likely, yes. And those organisms will be eaten by other organisms and they will move down the chain. Eventually, perhaps reaching one with consciousness. Awareness of existence. Will that mean you will eventually control and inhabit another body? Maybe. Consciousness is still a very abstract concept, and all that science can really say at this point is that it is the result of the electrical signals in your brain. But science cannot currently explain why we are here. Why you are conscious, why I am conscious. Or where consciousness even comes from. If two people reproduce and produce two clones, and those clones are in the exact same life situations, will those clones make the same choices? Will they be the same people? And if they are the same people, what does that mean? That someone’s personhood is really controlled by the environment around them, by their experiences? Doesn’t that mean that we must all technically have the same roots? Perhaps. It’s difficult for me to comprehend why I exist. I don’t want to believe anything, I want proof. And the fact that it is impossible to figure out where my consciousness came from and why I am here upsets me. I want reincarnation to be real. I want to, once I die, have no perception of time and thus when I end up in another body, to exist again in this world with a fresh new experience. I want that to be the case. Because logically it would make sense and it would explain why I am here. But if that isn’t the case, what is life even for? Why the hell does existence even exist? It’s a giant paradoxical problem, and the more I think about it, the more anxious I get about my future death. I don’t ever want to lose the people I love, but I know it is inevitable one day. Permanency is a comforting thought, but it isn’t reality. But, here is a thought. We all came from an organism before us. And that organism came from one before that. And if we keep going down the line, eventually we start going further into the past. Eventually to when life started. And if that’s the case, if life started from one random organism created through random changes in the universe, an organism that could reproduce, then we all come from the same roots. We all come from that organism. Could we say that we are all the same? I honestly don’t know. I feel, to answer what happens after one dies, we first need to find out what happens when one is born. How does their consciousness come to be? What causes them to be aware of their own existence and control their actions? And of course, someone could simply just say “it’s the brainwaves that do it”. But that’s not a good enough explanation. Because you are here, controlling your body. And, electrical signals simply being the culprit would indicate that the brain has no free will, that it’s the result of a control center that is conditioned to behave in such a way to survive. And if that were the case, why would I feel like I can control what I do? Why can I freely choose to jump off a bridge as I please?

What happens if the cryofreezing facilities suddenly lose power for an extended period of time? Additionally, how do they morally choose who is brought back first? Likely, since this is largely experimental, something is bound to go wrong and those people will have paid for a service that they will never receive (is this moral/ethical/just?). Of course, then, they would never know, but the point stands nonetheless. Finally, was the resurrected worm's memory simply just muscle memory, something that even recently deceased organisms have been known to portray? How can they prove that an organism can maintain higher functioning, something that is unique to the human species, and long term memory can remain intact before attempting to resurrect the first "patients?" Will these patients come back as completely different people? Then, of course, there is the theological question of the soul. Will one be able to retrieve their soul upon resurrection? These resurrections, to me, seem to be possible, but they will likely lead more to a type of human that is void of a soul. Seemingly alive on the outside but dead on the inside. A futuristic, reimagined version of a zombie.

nobody in my family was giving the choice to live or die. -they just died.... so I do not expect to be given a choice whether to die or not.   However,  I did learn about how the members of my family died ...what killed them...that unto it self told me about how to avoid dying too soon....What I learned about death is that eventually everyone forgets those who have passed away because they have to focus on their own lives -living is hard - death is easy....so what makes life so hard?  Life forces the living to interact with the world and to stay relevant in real time -keeping up that relationship and making your life worthwhile is a huge challenge...For some the impact of those relationships lives on in other people long after their death ...which is why TMT makes us think longer about justice a tad longer ....However, for most of us .in the prime of our lives we are important but in the sunset of our livews we  are unimportant....often once we die we are forgotten.... So what makes your life still  worth living?  well  as long as your life stays engaged with the world and you can maintain relationships that help you validate this in real time then you will find life has meaning because you gave it one  that is uniquely yours - your own two cents into that pot we call humanity.

I choose death. If I don't die, I can't be sure of my future medical condition or legal status. As decades pass I'll increasingly be surrounded by aliens with whom I share no common experiences. In fact, I may revive in exactly that condition -- thoroughly anachronistic and psychologically disoriented.

If I don't die I cannot be reborn. Only in the last few years have I become reconciled and willing to reincarnate.

Rebirth or revitalization-- Either way holds the terror of vulnerability, of losing the control gained over decades of painstaking effort.

This current life had a rough and painful start, one that I have no wish to experience again. Nonetheless it seems better to make a fresh start with the power of a genuinely new life, than to tackle the challenges while shackled to an old persona.

Wish me luck.

That's crazy, I was thinking to myself, the reason why nationalism is becoming to popular, and why we (including myself) push it as hard as we do, is due to our ACKNOWLEDGEMENT of death, which the experimental group proved, relatively. We aim to have a better future for our children and their children, as well as our nation as a whole. And due to our acknowledgment of death, we put more thought into the future, and into our actions. And while it wasn't definitive, the experimental group definitely reinforced my theory as having a sturdy ground to stand on. This was an interesting episode to say the least.

Edit: As for the second part where he talks to the woman about death, I believe what she said about people trying to find immortality, or even an extension to their life as being unhealthy, I believe to be incredibly ignorant, and a massive cope. I won't type my whole thoughts out, but I believe someone taking the initiative to fight what would be though to be inevitable, is a truly wonderful thing. Someone taking a chunk of their life to dedicate to something like even prolonging death for people is amazing, as long as it doesn't reach self-obsessed, and unhealthy levels. I mean, if you have a tumor, that's not easily removable, but has a CHANCE of working, thereby allowing you to live, will you just say "eh fuck it, death is inevitable, I'll just let the tumor go", no most people would fight, and if that's considered unhealthy, I don't wanna be healthy then

It’s important to make the distinction between wanting to die, and accepting that you will. I am of the belief of both, personally. At some point in time, I stopped wanting to die in the now, and rather just look forward to the thought that one day I will. I think based off personal experience, you don’t necessarily need a reason to want to die, because that isn’t always the case. I don’t think we should view it as a bad thing either. Yes, life is good, but if somebody genuinely just wants not be apart of it, then that’s cool too. I don’t think it should be considered selfish to want death, that’s a very narcissistic view to have. Somehow, the person should have to hold out because it’ll make others sad? Well, what about the person wanting death? I don’t know, I know it’s unpopular, but that’s my thoughts on the matter.

I don't think living forever is possible - like yeah maybe you can live like 200-300 years with all that technology and stuff but there is a limit. A limit when the tissues are simply too old to function with the same efficiency as when they were younger, or atleast, the efficiency needed to stay live. Now somebody could reply "But we can reverse the aging process" to this comment but I don't think that should be possible. Entropy. Things get old and we have no choice but to accept that things do get old and more disordered. So do tissues too. They are part of the universe so they should obey the laws of the universe. You can do nothing to stop it because you yourself are part of the universe too. No matter how much we try to slow down tissues from aging, there will be that one moment when they're all like "Enough. I'm done. Hey, tell goodbye to the world" and lights out.

I am not buying the death positivity expert's argument. I think that the idea that without death we would find no reason to get things done is demagoguery. I don't know exactly how much death has to do with me pursuing things I'm passionate and curious about, but I know it is not the only factor. If I were not going to die, I think I would still pursue them.

I've heard other people (including Neil deGrasse Tyson) rattle off a similar sentiment with a knowing smile, but I think it only really applies to people for whom legacy is the main concern. It's an argument that is better designed to score rhetorical points in debate than to address fear of death in the long term.

Death is a universal part of the cycle of nature, if we view nature as a generative process, then it needs death for constant growth, to stop the cycle from spinning would be a crime against nature, there is a generational contract in passing the fire of civilization to future generations, it's important to remember that we all must die some day and to do so with grace. If we all looked forward to our deaths like we look forward toward Christmas this world would be brave enough to face every social problem that we see today, perhaps a spiritual revolution is necessary because our modern mindset has put us out of touch with nature.

Here is my theory with the idea of tampering with life.  I won’t bring God into the equation because honestly you don’t need God for the theory I have come up with.  In fact, I wouldn’t even call it a theory, but more like common sense.  There is a rate at which we learn and gain wisdom and maturity as a human being.  Some peoples’ rates are faster or slower than others of course, but there is an average rate.  I believe that rate is connected to our lifespan.  If we looked back to when the average life span of a human being was around 40 or so years, people mentally developed faster.  Humans at the age of 16 and 18 were already married and raising a family as well as dealing with issues that adults dealt with. If we look now, it’s not uncommon for someone to be 20 and still live with their parents.  Families aren’t made until the late 20s to even early 40s.  Now to reach to the same level of maturity and have the same level wisdom as the people from the far past you must be around 60-70 years of age.  The guy in the video mentioned the world would be better off because people would gain wisdom and maturity infinitely.  But honestly I think the rate of how fast you gain maturity and wisdom would just flatten out and would take longer to reach that same level of maturity.  So not only will you have more “adult children” in the world, overpopulation would also become an even greater problem.  Death is our mental catalyst that determines how fast we mentally develop.

None of this is meaningful since we still have no real alternative to death. Any decision one makes is based on the inevitability of death. The cryogenic thing is very iffy at best. It's not just about "will science be able to make it work?" but also, the bigger risk, will the head or body stay frozen? That's very unlikely. More likely is that the company will go bust and no one will care to keep you frozen or some upheaval will take place that will result in the heads/bodies rotting away. There are just too many real world factors to overcome to make it all work. It's all totally unproven. So right now we don't really have a choice. Acceptance is not optional.

I'm surprised nobody brought up the topic of consciousness and ego/identity. Even if we advance to the point of "reviving" these people's bodies and brains, the consciousness, which is "you", would be long gone. There's simply no conceivable way to bring back someone's identity and consciousness through physical means. It's a byproduct of our brain chemistry, and the moment it goes dark, no amount of cryogenics can undo that. You're gone forever. I can respect the intelligence behind the science of Alcor and similar organizations, but it all comes off as very desperate and delusional.

if I were to be frozen at the point of death and revived many years in the future i may not recognise or feel a part of the world, with nobody i remember in my life that gave my life meaning or a world I don't recognise will I truly feel that it was worth it. After the novelty of seeing the future passes would I regret being brought back to life? When I think about it I don't think I would like to be frozen. Over the last ten years of my life I have been forced to face my own mortality and possible early death as on five separate occasions over this past decade I have been given the dreaded cancer diagnosis, once it was stage 4. This January I was told the cancer that was once in my lung had spread to my brain, thankfully after 8 months of treatment I am now again in remission. i have faced the possibility of an early death 5 times now but it hasn't changed my absolute fear of dying, it still fills me with immense terror and the only reason I feel like this is because I still have strong attachment to the living and the thought of not being a part of their lives is the only thing keeping me from accepting death as a positive. Perhaps years in the future when they are gone i will want to follow along and gratefully accept death but right now its the one thing I fear the most.

I’m not gonna freeze myself, that’s wack af in my opinion.
Imagine choosing to a neuro, and waking up in the distant future as a living head, or a head attached to some kind of mechanism that could act as a body.
And now imagine you wake up in a completely foreign, futuristic world that does not at all resemble the world you died in.
On top of that, we have to remember that this is something that is still being researched.
And as a result, I can guarantee at least a handful of people will be unhappy with the results.
My teacher once told us he used to freeze rats when he was younger, to experiment on them. He unfroze them, and they were able to survive. However, he also found many of them were blind, or damaged in some other way.
I know, one day cryogenically freezing and reviving people may very well be safe and all good one day.
But for now, we simply cannot predict the outcome.
I am choosing to accept my mortality, because it is who I am, it is how I was born, and it is how I was intended to live.

comment_text: to a certain degree you could compare cryogenics to the advent of motor vehicles, yeah life would probably be better if we could get places without having to walk or use horses, but just how much and in what way do we want to accommodate ourselves in that desire? At the mercy of industrial capitalists we got here, what happens in a hundred years when we realize that freezing and unfreezing people causes an ecological disaster, yet we still have thousands of sleepers expecting to wake up?

Is it legal for ALCOR to do this cryo preserving thing while they clearly say that we don't know how to revive the "patients"?
It seems unacceptable tbh

I think that regardless of whether or not we should accept death, Alcor is actually onto something, because not only bringing someone back from the dead extends their own life but it also allows us to have a better understanding about what death really is and what comes after; which would make it easier for us to decide if we want to die or not. After all, what scares most people about death is the mystery of what it's all about. Also the mortician lady has a point about the avoidance of death being kind of too obsessive in a way, but if you think about it, just because the technology exists doesn't mean EVERYBODY is going to want to use it, it's a matter of choice. I think that as important as it is to deal with our own mortality, it is also interesting to know what the experience of death consists of so that we come to a better understanding of existence.

I am in conflict with death since i was 12 when i had a panic attack thinking i was going to die. Since then i am unable to stop thinking about death. Not that i would limit my behaviour fearing death as an outcome but i did limit my life expectancy by a lot. I went into a state of nihilism. Life is worthless, life is short and everything you will do in your life will end in the same way: dying. This thought process never left me and positive thinking like you should live life to its fullest because you only have one just doesnt cut it for me. Sure i will enjoy life but i will not think it matters to any extent. Ill be dead in the end anyway and all the love and achievements i gain will be lost in a flash. When i got older at like 20 i started getting more more interested into astronomy. Space and the vastness of it. At first this put my nihilism in overdrive making myself feel less and less significant. The thought of how small we are smaller then we see ants compared to the vastness of space and planets/stars just destroys your ego. Later in an older age i started thinking about it differently i started to feel part of an extremely complex world, a world my brain cant even comprehend. The universe feels like an incredible work of art an infinite possibilities of beauty and destruction and we are part of it. But this bring me to my current state of mind. A world "the universe" All created by pure chance. We do not know exactly what started the official "start, big bang" or the universe but we do know everything that followed is pure chance. There is a chance a planet is made, a chance a star is lit, a chance a planet orbits a sun at the right distance, a chance for water to be on this planet, a chance for bacteria to evolve and ultimately for natural selection and biological evolution to take place for such a long time of trail and error pure by chance and survival rates for a more advanced animal. Slowly created by pure genetic mistakes that happen to have a possitive outcome.  It is all pure roll of the dice the entire universe is a roll of the dice. This got my back into a nihilistic way of thinking feeling like anything just exists by chance. it has zero meaning what so ever. There is no reason we are alive its just because it got the chance to.  There is no reason to being alive it was a roll of the dice and what we make of our lives and call it a reason to live is made by our own consciousness we all tell our selves a different story that we ourself claim to be the right path and the way it should be. But its all fabricated in our brain, Its an illusion. The only thing that could be considered a reason to live is reproduction. But with over-population coming our way that is quickly dismissed as well. I am unable to lie to myself and call my self important the only thing that is important to me is that the universe will give chance to anything that can become and will become, everything to live once and die once like a star.

Immortality will come. But not as an organism but as a robot. Inprinting our conciousness/brain into a harddrive for a robot and that will continue to live forever. We will try to keep ourselves immortal but the technology will be the end game in immortality.

Does anyone else think that all those ppl who are trying to "cheat death" are just egotistical as well as being totally inconsiderate to the future generations to come?
I mean, even though I can't say I'm totally comfortable with the thought that I will die at some point or another - I'm still confident that we all would be better off trying, to the best of our ability to just accept it as the natural part of life that it is!

And not "only" since it's an irrefutable and completely natural part of life - but not least since we would otherwise further rob future generations of their rightful need of resources!!!

At least think about it: we, as well as AT LEAST the last 5 - 7 generations before us have, at an unprecedented rate been robbing our future generations of a lot of the resources that should have been, and was rightfully theirs! Which as a consequence have put the coming generations (and probably ourselves as well) in a very hard spot when it comes to the health of our planet.
And all for what? Because of the modern world's perverted misguided glorification of greed, power-hunger and stupidity/ignorance....
Traits which at least I believe can be attributed to as being the driving-force behind most (if not all) of the current epidemics that we all know have sky-rocketed within especially the so called "developed world"; that is diseases such as for ex. obesity, diabetes, depression, stress related-, anxiety- and personality-disorders (to just name a few). Areas which correspond to he exact same places where those perverted traits mentioned above have been the prevailing ones.
Which perhaps aren't so surprising when considering that those traits are actually the exact polar-opposites of "real", or wholesome virtues such as generosity/sharing, contentment and wisdom!
Virtues, or values that I believe desperately needs to be restored, and quickly - not "just" because of our and our planet's survival, but also for our well-being!

Well, just my 2 cents. You don't have to agree of course - and if you don't, please let me know both why and how so. Thanks!

Counterargument to death being what makes you do things you want to do:
You won't procrastinate for hundreds of years just because you can. If that was the case you would see people in normal society procrastinating for years on a passion they have. People don't start being creative or seeking their dream job after they get old enough to realize they are living on borrowed time, they start seeking it when it becomes available and they realize that is their passion.

Edit: also you still only live once if you are unable to die (even if it's just cured aging) because even if you have thousands or millions of years to do anything you still have to live with all the choices you make in life.
If you knew you were immortal and didn't fight for what you believed in and then that fight was lost you live with the regret of having been able to possibly weigh the scales in your favor

I'm not sure that "terror management" is the best term. Consciousness of my own mortality might make me a more deliberate judge - but it doesn't mean I have any fear of my own mortality. The 'terror' in the term is misleading. It implies only the people who are afraid of death will be affected by this phenomenon, which doesn't seem to be true. I can actually love the impermanence of life and look forward to the rest of death after a life well lived and still be more deliberate in my judgments for the sake of the future.

but with longer life, the value of the time you spend decreases. it's economy 101. the more there is of X the less it's worth. and the ever flowing, ever changing nature of life is what makes it beautiful. the fact that your wisdom and physical health intersect is just a fact of that. consider every year you spend honing your physical attributes will make you more physically healthy for longer, every year spent honing mental attibutes makes you smarter and wiser. so by the time we're all 80, we all have unique experiences, each a single mollecule of uniquely coloured paint on the great, vast canvas of humanity when "our time" comes. but if you take that away, by the time we've reached "the end" we've all lived 1000, 10000 whatever years, we've all done more and as a result there's gonna be significantly more overlap in our experiences, memories, history. we'll all have identical lives. finite possible experiences and choices with indefinate possible future l;iterally strips away our personalities, our individualities, heck even our morals if you subscribe to the law of large numbers. every road will eventually be travelled by every person, the good, the evil, the passive and the chaotic. so what difference would there be between me after walking every possible path and every choice VS you after all that too? life has meaning because of it's finite amount. if you squander and waste it then you did just that. if we live for thousands of years? people are literally gonna procrastinate fixing the sink for decades if not longer!

On ome hand i think death kind of refreshes the world, people die and people are born. Thanks to death there is no Adolf Hitler or Stalin, and there will be no Donald Trump on Kim Jong Un in the future, but also we've lost Albert Einstein, Stephen Hawking, Isaac Newton, and, of course (if everything said about how great he was is true), Jesus.

So in the end death may not really be that good of a thing, it feels like it sort of limits the risks of letting people live too long to become a danger to others, but if people's life was extended, as Max (Alcor's CEO) said, people could become better over time, you know, wiser and all of that; i personally also believe their motivations to do horrible things would be reduced since they wouldn't need to if they weren't going to die, but that may be more related to TMT, because if there's no fear of death, they wouldn't try to push their views onto other people as much.

Something else i think about is if death helps us live better, being more humble and considerate of others, because death in most cases means loss and pain for someone else, so it sort of unites us, and rips us apart at the same time, possibly turning us bitter, maybe even vengeful against this merciless world we live in.

So again, it is very hard to determine if we should really stop death, because with every bad thing it brings, there is a counter-example showing an equivalent good thing it brings, and viceversa.

So i'm not really sure if we should try not to die. My plan currently is to just live without worrying too much about if i die tomorrow or in a thousand years, but whatever happens, i just hope i come to a conclussion about all this and decide if i embrace death or reject it, instead of having no answer.

Honestly, I find both the concept of death and the idea of living forever to be equally terrifying

If I die, I cease to exist, and I am incapable of imagining myself as not existing, as existing is literally everything I know, and this fills me with pure terror

If I live forever, whether by actual immortality, or an eternal afterlife, then there is a 100% possibility that I will eventually do, think, and say everything here is to do, think, and say

And that moment of having experienced everything there is to experience will occur within an arbitrarily large, but still finite amount of time, and then I still have the entirety of forever left ahead of me, with the only thing left being absolute boredom, and that would be the worst kind of hell

And the worst part is that these are the only 2 possible outcomes, even if I were to live for 500 googolplexian years, there is still that cessation of existence at the end

My answer thirty seconds in:
I would choose to live forever...
Provided we could figure out how to have the body genetically regenerate so that parts are absorbed and replaced by new ones. This would be tricky for the brain unless our nerves could be regenerated internally like shedding it’s outer layers. Keeping us at the peak of our genetic design.
Only then would the length of life time become a problem for those who have trouble with loss.
If I could live forever but everyone else didn’t want too. Then I would loss every one. Many suggest this would be a big issue.
I say no, it’s not. At least not for me since knowing death would be a choice. If every one chose to die, well... that would be their choice. Plus, who am I to tell them what to choose? From a young age we lose friends, though not to death but to simply moving away and what not. Today, when a person dies of “natural” causes we learn to accept and move on in life keeping the dead in our memories.
So acceptance and freedom of choice to accept such loss makes this easy for me. If you want to die, that’s your choice and I will accept what to choose to do with yourself in your life. I’ll live on happily knowing that time is nothing but our own creation and, without aging, can continue to enjoy the life I live.
That brings us to our reality, though...
We can’t by choose live without dying, yet.
So as we get old and wither within a crusty shell that hurts more with the passing of days would I still want to live?
Hell, yes I would. The only thing that could change my mind is dementia or Alzheimer’s...
I’d have to forget how much I love living to say I’m ready to quit living. Let me grow old and senile.
Death sucks. Rotting away while creepy crawlers chew on my parts doesn’t sound like a good vacation from life. Just saying 🤗

Edited to add my 30 min in statement:

Holy 💩! I want to see the process for the head removal! I digress...

Okay that’s insane... chill the body for a chance at a future with meds that prolong life... hmmm.
Not sure I’d want that but if I had disposable income... maybe.
I was thinking when I die I’d like to be donated to the Body Worlds exhibit but now I’m not so sure...
With the new options available the future could be a brighter place. Yet, imagine awakening like RoboCop!
The doctor telling you that it’s been thousands of years and the best they could do was build your body as a prosthetic extension! WHOA!
Okay let’s get real...
If I could genetically live till some action murdered me what would I do? I’d work to explore the cosmos. Think about it. If every one could live with out death we would have too many people. So I’d leave the planet. Branch out. Helping humanity become multi planetary. That would be an amazing journey. I’m game.

This is a very interesting video. But I think the fundamental flaw with it is the assumption people don't want to die. What if someone wants to die, but continues to live because of various reasons pushed upon them by outside forces such as family or society? And it failed to answer why we should choose to continue living. To want to be alive while also accepting we will die some day is to fear death, avoid death and to continue living. You can still fear and avoid death while also accepting that it will happen eventually, but are you truly accepting it, or disregarding what you cannot control and in essence it's a fancy way of denying it.

The fact you will die does not give your actions meaning, the intent and results of your actions gives them meaning. If someone dies saving another life, we deem that action good. If someone takes their own life to end someone else's we deem that as a bad action. If your reason for living is to do good, then you should want to live for as long as possible. If you reach a state of being where you are no longer able to do whatever your reasons for living are, you loose your reasons to choose life and you want to die. This may explain why elderly people sometimes want to die, it probably also explains why David Attenborough has not retired yet.

The massive issue at its core is the reason for living or dying is unique to each and every individual person. So the most horrible thing about the question "should I die" is that can only be answered by you AND the question itself can only be constructed by you, it's a philosophical loop you both open and close. In my opinion there is a number of reasons for each person to be alive, each reason is crafted and cared for by the individual alone. There are also reasons to die, depending on the person these reasons to die increase or decrease. As long as your reasons to live out weigh (not out number) your reasons for death you will choose to continue living.

I personally see no reason to die, I don't believe in an after life and I know the world and universe will keep going once I am gone. I also don't see many reasons for living, there's no purpose in personal gain as it will mean nothing when I die, and why help others because it wont mean anything when they die and of course we're all going to die eventually and at any time. This also means my bar for wanting to stay alive is very low, doing good and having fun is enough for me to choose to keep living. Sadly for some people, they live with too much pain and have had too many reasons stripped away from them to choose life.

At the end of the day there is no reason to live or die. Everything that we value or what gives us purpose is a construct of our personality shaped by our genetics and experiences. Morty says it best "life has no meaning, we're all going to die, come watch some tv". To be in complete denial and ignorance of death might be the most alive you could ever possibly be.

In my opinion it's crazy to accept death. We know it's wrong. We know how painful it is, and how it can make us anxious. We know how much we can delude ourselves to sooth our minds. Why not face it ? Death is not an absolute of nature, of life, some animals don't die (some simple animals, look it up) cancerous cells can be immortal, most plants can be crafted and start anew.

We and all other living beings are the way we are now because of evolution. Natural selection is one of the best tools to understand why we are how we are. There is an upside to living longer, or living longer healthy, as it allows more time to reproduce. However the longer the being lives, the more likely it is to die in the current year, let's say.
Another factor that prevents natural selection from selecting people with a longer life-span is the average at which they reproduce.
If there's people that reproduce early and will go on to live very short lives, that mutation is just as likely to be part of the gene pool than other mutations that improves life conditions for the elderly.

Basically, living a longer life is not a strong evolutionary advantage, and thus hasn't been selected for that much. I say this but perhaps the few centuries some animals can live is already a tremendous success of evolution ... depends on how you want to look at it.


Anyways, we don't have to be constrained by evolution. We are aware that we're biological animals. It's not logical to accept death, as inevitable as it is in the long run (even an immortal will have an accident, be it ten days from now, or a billion years).

This whole cryogenic thing is just making money from scared people. The only proven cases of 'freezing' then coming alive again is done in a very short period of time. By the time this technology would possibly become available, these bodies wouldn't qualify. In fact, it would probably require much more advanced chemicals that we have yet to discover/create.
