You see Michael, you don't have Treatment Resistant Depression. People who do have it and people who have severe chronic pain, or both (like myself) often just want an end to all experience. Because their lives are filled with so much suffering that experiencing things becomes not worth it. And in rare periods of improvement, even those periods are darkened by the thought that they too will quickly end, and more suffering will ensue. We want a cure, or at least an ongoing treatment that works, but the truth is - both healthcare and the pharmaceutical industry have largely given up on us. We don't think that there will be a cure or even an effective treatment within our lifetime, it's probably unrealistic to believe this, - a fool's hope. But society and families will not let us go. It's fine when it's our bodies that kill us (cancer, stroke, etc.) but somehow not OK when it's our brains that kill us? Because this is what suicide is - it's wrong to think that there really is some kind of choice when it comes to this. Our brains are predisposed to gamble with death until one day we pop too many pills, take our food and water fasting 2-3 days too far and so on. Depression kills, chronic pain kills. Society won't acknowledge it. Our families are more unhappy watching us suffer when we are alive. If we were to die: it would be a terrible loss for them, but eventually it will get better. But while we are alive: it won't get better, - it's a perpetuated cycle of suffering. There should be an option of euthanasia for Treatment Resistant Depression the same way there is one for terminal illnesses of the body. We should be free to liberate ourselves, our families, our friends, our loved ones from suffering our unhappy brains put them through. And in this respect: cryogenic facilities make sense, because it's entirely possible that one day MDD will be a thing of the past and chronic pain will be successfully treated, so we could once again be revived but this time : enjoy the rest of our days.

I disagree with the notion that I only do things because of my mortality. It's a lazy argument. I don't actually believe that I'm going to die, I've used one of those denial mechanisms that she talks about: I'm rich, I'm young and medicine is advancing very quickly, so there's a good chance that I won't die at all. Yet that hasn't stopped me from doing things.

Sure, if I found out I was dying soon I'd do a lot MORE things, but that's not the same as saying that I wouldn't be appreciating life properly if I knew I was going to live forever.

Alcor seems like a devious company. Call me old fashioned but I think the acceptance of death is a part of maturity and being human. That’s not to say that I don’t understand their sentiment but death isn’t something to be “helped.” It’s something that happens all the time at every level of existence. Also the argument that living longer will make you smarter is idiotic. Have you taken a stroll through an old folks home? Sure there are people who manage to remain a functioning human but it’s obvious that it’s not in our nature to live forever. I’m sure there would be a whole gamut of mental disorders that we are not at all prepared for in the case of living forever.

While it seems logical for the majority, it could have been made clearer by actually spelling out on the form what every number means (for example 2: 6 months 3: 1 year, 4: 2 years, 5: 4 years, 6: 7 years). So I think the results from people who never choose anything betwen should be discarded, which could have made the effect clearer.

Also I think that since the hypothesis was that people would punish things opposing their world views more severely, but you don't know which questions would be more opposing world views than others, a more interesting way to analyze the results could have been comparing the group average per crime against each other. Maybe there would have been a clear tendency for some crimes up, but some not being affected, some even going down. The average per person on a set of entirely different crimes and the total average don't really seem to tell very much, except for a general tendency being for or against higher punishment.

Mathematical exposition and analysis on the Vsauce channel is usually sound but I did notice misleading analysis on the terror management segment. When conducting a hypothesis test it is improper to add variables post hoc based on perceived statistical significance and then analyze the new variables statistical significance, as they did with response time. At most this should raise a flag to test the additional variable in a new independent study.

This is because in general the more variables you are testing the more extreme a deviation from the control has to be for any one of the deviations to be significant. And when you pick variables to analyze post hoc it isn't clear how many variables you are actually testing for and thus makes statistical analysis impossible to perform.

On mortality management theory, or whatever it's called, I think they may have correctly observed the phenomenon but given it a really bad explanation. It's not because knowing you're going to die makes you want to pass on your identity more than normal, it's because if you're afraid that your community is in danger, knowing that the stakes are higher you're willing to tolerate less experimentation with novelty, as it could be risky. The cost benefit analysis changes. It's like the risk of somebody eating a donut who has no nut allergy vs. someone who does have one when another donut in the shop has nuts on it. Novelty can yield high rewards, but it can also come at a certain risk.

We should indeed, die. And here's my reasoning; You don't know me, but if there's a god and a heaven or hell, I would rather go to hell. Not because I am an edgy teen with a demon complex, but because eternity in heaven would bore me. Sure, the first few years would be cool. Unlimited food, drinks, games, whatever there is that makes heaven so great. But after a long time, food would taste stale, games would have been played over and over. "what if heaven discovers new things, though?" At some point, everything will be discovered. Nothing will be satisfying enough, and the torture of knowing you'll exist, forever, in a place you can't get out of would be a nightmare. Heaven, would be my own personal hell. "So why hell?" Because if the hell-heaven theory is true, I would rather be punished and be in pain for eternity, than be bored for eternity. And if we would live on forever, eventually our sun, will burst. And we'd all suffer incredible pain, to then finally die and be introduced to a whole new world of things that have already be discovered. Another reason why we should die, is because of overpopulation. Overpopulation is, in fact, NOT being caused by the many births of children all over the world, but because people are getting much and much older. When I have to get a job, I will be taking care of 6 elders' pensions, instead of what the average adult cares for now; 2. (In The Netherlands.) Why is that? Because people are getting old, and there's less and less children being born. We, who are not so big in numbers anymore, will have to take care of our elders, who are with many. So yes, we should die. And one more reason. In order for new flowers to grow, you must get rid of weeds. Which basically means, in order for us, Millennials and Gen Z to develop, spread our wings and fix the world our dear beloved ancestors left so destroyed, we must get rid of their old ways. And habits die hard, but the old ways like: 'same sex marriage only' 'no people of color' or well, 'do anything out of the norm of society.' we all know that our society is changing, due to us, the younger generations, creating our own. This does not mean that all older generations are a bunch of shitbags, it means that what was once normal for them, is not normal anymore. And that's due to us changing it, together. But the fact that people are becoming much much older makes it harder for these traditions to die, because there's still a part of the population judging us for being abnormal to their standards. It sounds harsh, and it is, but in order for us to grow, the elder should eventually die out. TL;DR: Living too long or forever would get boring because eventually nothing new would be discovered, Overpopulation is being caused by people growing much older, and for our newest generations to grow, we need the old ones to die out.

Ok, but I have a some questions.


if you were cryogenically frozen, what would happen in terms of beliefs on heaven and hell or reincarnation?


For example, would being cryogenically frozen delay you going to heaven or hell?
(not that that is what I believe but say it does end up being real).


Or take reincarnation and things such as your soul/spirit.


would your soul/spirit still leave your body once you die?


And if that does happen what would happen once you were brought back?
would you be a different person? retain memory and beliefs?


and if you do keep your soul/spirit would you be trapped?



Also, I think another key thing we need to think about is, say that being cryogenically frozen becomes a norm or something popular and frequently done even if only amongst the rich or wealthy.


Where would we get the space to keep all of these cryogenically frozen bodies?


what would maintaining these bodies require in terms of resources and how would this affect the currently alive population?


and if these people are able to be brought back how would we cope with and accommodate to the steady increase in population growth?


There is an already huge population of homeless people worldwide.
where would we get the room to provide housing for this increase in people?


what about things like resources? how would we be able to produce enough food for everyone? where would we get the land to grow all of this food? especially if we have to make room for more housing.


other resources such as oil, water, fossil fuels etc are already running out or are scarce in certain areas.


how would we sustain society without those things?


if we did find replacements for them such as using solar power instead of fossil fuels,
we don't know how long it would take for us to be able to completely rely on solar power or what that would require in terms of how much land we would need, how many resources it would require etc.


how would our environment be affected? our climate is already suffering due to the use of fossil fuels.
what would happen if we had to use even more of these resources to support everyone?


forests would have to be cut down to make room for new housing as well as for resources such as wood and paper.


Things such as plastic pollution in oceans would become even worse


more wildlife would become endangered or even extinct.


What political issues could this bring up?


being cryogenically frozen is something that only wealthy or rich people would have the money for.
The people who are the most wealthy in our world are quite often leaders or influences.


if these people could afford to live 'forever' how would this affect us?


how would we continue to have new leaders and new influences if the old ones never die?


would the newer generations be unable to have their turn to lead or be given fewer opportunities than those who are already wealthy and have a high position in society?


in my opinion, I believe our world is currently much too unstable in terms of our future to be thinking about keeping people alive for 100+ years.



once we sort out things such as climate change and find a reliable source of power that doesn't damage our environment, find ways to eliminate the uses of plastics to prevent things such as pollution in our oceans and coral bleaching, find solutions to improving homelessness, and find a way to provide the amount of resources needed to keep an even bigger population happy, healthy and safe then we can begin to think of the possibility of increased life span or even 'immortality"


I don't know that is just my personal opinion, feel free to leave your own opinions/ideas/solutions i would love to hear any ideas or views people have.

Ok so here is one thought i had while watching this: What happens to the consciousness/soul of these people who become patients at Alcor? Depending on what you - reader - believe happens to your consciousness/soul in the moment you die, raises some fundamental questions about what our consciousness is. Is it created by the brain? or is it an "essence" in us that leaves the body a soon as we die. If in let's say... 50 years, the first of these Alcor patients get revived - and let's assume our consciousness is an essence leaving our body in the moment we die - what will happen to that first person being revived? This moment would answer a fundamental question about what consciousness is and if it's being created by our brain itself or not. Because if our consciousness is an essence, getting reincarnated into another living being after our death - then according to this belief all these patients who'd get revived would be without a consciousness - because their consciousness already lives on in another body. The cryopreserving thing is insane. Who would want that done to their body? And what if a future tyrannical government restores you to life, just to do horrific, torturous medical experiments on you? And what's the point of wanting to be revived in the future anyway? Once you've had kids and they've survived to adulthood, there's no real reason to keep living.

Furthermore, every death has a specific medical cause, not just "old age". Heart failure, lung failure, those are the specific events that end a person's life. So for each person cryopreserved, their specific cause of death would need fixing. I.e. a person who died of heart failure would probably need a heart transplant, or at least something to give them a functional heart again.

And here's another thing: people trying to live indefinitely could definitely cause conflicts, because it creates more competition for resources like food, space, housing, which are needed to live. Furthermore, if an old person, cryogenically preserved, is restored, and their heart is replaced let's say (since, let's say, heart failure was the cause of their death) - they will still be an old and frail person in the rest of their body. So they will not be productive. And therefore society will have to support them with elderly care. And will future working-age humans put up with this? It's not unreasonable to imagine they might ban people trying to cryogenically preserve themselves and restore themselves, because it might put too much strain on society's resources.

Unless the revived person gets some sort of robot body, but then who's paying for the robot? If they're rich enough that their estate can pay for it, then fine. But otherwise, I don't think the working-age population will want to fund robot bodies for revived people. Even if the revived person with a robot body could be productive, you're having to spend money on the robot body to make them productive, whereas a working-age human being is productive without that expense.

I can't help but feel like the first experiment had some built in bias into the sample pool. It seems as if everyone in the control group was fairly young, only a few of them seemed to be around the age of 50 and only one appeared to be significantly older. Therefore, they are less likely to be worried about impeding death. However, with the exception of the one younger male, everyone in the experimental group appeared to be around the age of 50 with many looking as if they could be in their 60s or 70s and would naturally be much more aware of their own mortality. I would love to see this experiment run, if it hasn't been already, with a larger and much more diverse pool of test subjects.

We've been pushing death backwards for ages now. Life expectancy has gone up decades. Why would this arbitrary lifespan people happen to get to now be the 'natural death we should accept'? Everyone will die at some point, it's simply inevitable, if only for the fact that entropy exists. But the 90ish years we have now has no right to be our final max age. Reversing aging is more than likely possible. Imagine not only having far more time on your hands, but also having your youth for all that time. Not having grown tired and weary after 50 years of work, but still feeling like you did when you were 20. You're just given so much more time to enjoy the things you like in life. Read that other book you just hadn't gotten to yet. Finally pick up on that hobby that always interested you, but you never found time for yet Sure, with more time on your hands, you will procrastinate more too, but does that really matter? We already do that anyway. It's not like you'll be actually immortal, you can still die in an accident, or anything like that. Even if you upload your mind if that becomes possible. Your file can get corrupted, deleted, damaged. Even with all the backups and fail safes, though you may grow to be eons old, at some point it will fail, and you will die. ..but you sure had a far longer and more meaningful run than any of us could have.

I have some pretty serious depression brought on by thinking about my own mortality, and am firmly in the camp of "Death is bad". Frankly the question of, "Should I Die?" Has literally always been a no-brainer to me. No, and thinking anything to the contrary is insane to me. Yet here I am watching this video because I can't stop thinking about it. Gotta love how the brain fixates on what it perceives as a threat. I actually get pissed off when I hear people who say that, trying to live forever is bad, that death gives meaning and that it's bad that people like me think dying is bad. My daily existential dread isn't granting me increased drive in my life, I'm literally clinically depressed and don't get much of anything done because of it. As for whether immortality is "sensible"... if you mean feasible and a thing we should do? I don't know if it's doable, I don't know if there is or is not a way to avoid random chance that will doom us. I do think that opposing technology to end death, working against what people like me are desperately hoping for, is kind of shitty. You want to die, you do that, but please don't be the one that protests when the immortality technology starts getting developed. Anyone who does that is killing others in a roundabout way.

As for cryo-preservation... These people aren't being fed nutrients. So basically, the neural structure of their brains might be preserved, their flesh is still there, but there is no brain activity. They are, in fact, brain dead? Because if so, that's not immortality as far as I'm concerned. That's a bit of an issue of philosophy, I understand, but I'm still not seeing any current preservation technology.

As for "Eventually, something's going to get you." Well... maybe? Maybe I'm delusional, maybe I'm just being hopeful because I'm so freaked out that it's literally manifested into mental illness. But, couldn't you say the same thing about smallpox eventually getting you? If you make it through humanity's advancement, ideally, we eventually get enough control and knowledge to start eliminating random factors that cause deaths. We start modifying human minds to progress faster, or even develop AI (and don't fuck that up), we can advance exponentially, very rapidly. We eventually get control of enough that even gamma ray bursts are things we'll defend against. Heat Death? I don't know what to do about that. But ideally, if we can control for everything else, maybe there's something we can do about that. A chance is better than what we have right now. Right now, all we have is certainty in the wrong direction.

Perhaps the TMT experiment didn't have enough of a delay between the mortality salience and the opinion test. For explicit mortality salience (MS) primes (as opposed to subliminal) longer post-MS manipulation intervals (10-20min) with 2-3 distraction tasks (before the opinion tests) generate a greater effect than shorter intervals with a single task.
There's personal variability in the distraction requirements and speed at which the intervals push thoughts of death into the unconscious and elicit worldview defense—partly modulated by the level of self-esteem.
Robert Trivers, in a paper on self deception https://www.mercatus.org/system/files/The_Elements_of_a_Scientific_Theory_of_Self-Deception.pdf mentioned a study about voice discernment and galvanic skin response. He identified two styles of self deception (modulated also partly by self-esteem): projectors and deniers.
The "deniers", showing the higher levels of arousal, are quicker to push thoughts into the unconscious.
The results of a TMT study with a short interval and a single distraction task after MS manipulation vary depending on the percentage of "deniers" in the study.

This is a very interesting episode that is making me think a lot of things.


First of all the age old question as what do we consider as 'self', is it our body, is it our brain or is it just the information stored in our brain. As a conscious being if I put all information of myself into another vessel. Do I become that vessel. Or instead if I make a copy, do I exist as both of them at the same time. The work people at Alcor are doing. It's interesting. If they fail to revive people, than that's fine, no loss there. If they do succeed, the year might be 3023, still to the patient it would be just a matter of few seconds before they regain consciousness.


My question is, say Alcor succeeds in creating an undying machine to house our conscience. How long a life is enough life? Is it till the point where Earth is no longer habitable, is it till the point our Sun burns out, is it till the point all the stars dim out, is it till the point where the black holes are no longer a viable source of energy. He is correct that a longer life can hold more value to an individual, such as owning 10kg of gold is worth more than owning 5kg of gold. "immortality" would really change other bits of morality. The death sentence becomes so much worse, but also so does murder. 10 years in prison is no longer 10% or more of your time. Colleges will be filled with more mature people as people in their 40's,50's,60's or even 90's decide to finally pursue an education without fear this its a waste of time. Time no longer becomes a resource. But at the same time disaster also becomes far more scary. We all know we will die some day, but if you didn't suddenly being confronted with destruction you could not come back from becomes darker. Faith in a afterlife will fade over time and the coping mechanisms we have adapted as a society will disappear. Its so hard to loose a child because you subconsciously know you will die before them and when it doesn't work that way it hits you hard. Now imagine a world where you never thought you would loose anybody, its not in movies, books, or in life anymore but a house fire takes one of your friends. How much worse would that be in a world without inevitable death?

It seems to me like the goal of just, existing as a conscious and intelligent being, should neither be total immortality or suicide in 5 minutes (or anti-natal "better never to have been" stuff), but rather something like completion of the self or something. If I believe that I have had a good turn on this rock and would like to share it by making room for future people, then I should probably hang up my existential coat and die when my time has come. If I believe that I just haven't had enough time, or I feel like I could truly flesh out my curiosities only if I had a life extension, then by all means I should put all my chips on genetic modification, or robotics, or skynet, or ALCOR.


Either way, the problem I see left and right are miserable bastards just begging to stop the ride as soon as possible, or lunatic doc-brown types desperately trying to cling onto any shred of being for as long as possible, no matter the cost, no matter the consequences. It would seem then that living and then dying should not be seen as a curse (antinatalists and immortalists funnily enough agree that it is), but to rather view it as something like a carousel . It is a ride worth trying out at least once, but you should not be coerced to get off soon or stay on indefinitely; to do so undermines the joy of the ride itself. The meaning , if you will, of the ride is not given based on borrowed time (i.e. you have to get off at some point so you better enjoy it quick, because once you're off, you're off) nor in how long you can keep it running (i.e. you have been given an amazing opportunity, for the love of god don't you dare stop, because once you're off, you're off).


Just the concept of being comfortable with leaving the ride at all should, in my opinion, be wholly embraced. As conscious beings, we've been granted a surprisingly unique position in the universe as we know it, and maybe we're more scarce than we think. Most things that exist don't even get a chance to ride the carousel in the first place, even other living things; even other people.


The carousel of life is not ? meaninged ? by either it's total sanctity nor it's total futility. The ride is neither a mistake nor something to desperately cling on to forever. Do not be terrified of stepping off the ride, and do not try and jump off as soon as you can; be amazed at it's outstanding wonder, yet be happy to say goodbye at a moment's notice. Embrace the ride's utter impermanence and absurdity, yet also embrace how cool it is to even get to ride it at all. Take it in stride, but don't ignore why you're on it, or that you'll get off it. One of the greatest powers you have is that is that you can decide fully, on your own terms, when you are ready to leave the ride. The goal of a species of intelligent beings should be to make sure that the ride offers no persuasion to either staying on as long as possible, nor getting off as soon as possible.


We are an endurant species, and are surprisingly good at figuring out why what we do is worth it. If you take anything from this, it should be that you came from this world due to forces out of your control, be it your parents, God, evolution, the big bang, whatever; and you will most likely leave due to other forces out of your control, be it disease, aging, war, entropy, heat death, whatever. However, if we combine our collective undeserved, temporary brain power, we might be able to put the ball back in our court, where conscious life can seize the control panel of the carousel; where we can stop the time limit, and set our own. A ride where we don't have to ensure another rider takes our place due to time constraints (procreation) nor be forced to step off (preventable death). A life where we can relax, be grateful that we are here, knowing that we are here because our parents and ancestors weren't required to make us, but did so purely to introduce us to what the believed was a worthwhile experience; and a life where we die not because we are forced, but because we determine when we'd like to go.


I think it should be our next human goal to alleviate as best as we can our desperate factors that drive us to put aside our own conscious experience of life, like endless reproduction and unsatisfactorily short lives. We don't need to be immortal, just have enough time to not worry so hard about the end; to have enough time to make correct decisions, and to allow human kind to achieve peace with itself, where we do not curse our ancestors for bringing us into being without consent, nor de we dread our future for taking us out without our consent.


We have the power to turn affliction into opportunity, and there's no reason to think any idea is too far-fetched, we've been turning impossibilities possible for a couple thousand years now ;)

tldr:
Death is best approached when we lighten its grip enough so that we have time to make sense of it and then choose our way out before it takes us. You don't need to stay alive for eternity for your life to be worthwhile, nor should you cut to the chase and end it early because of fear for the future, nor wish that you never even existed in the first place. Life is a crazy opportunity you are incomprehensibly lucky to even have, but it has its problems nonetheless. If human history is an indication of anything, we aren't even close to being unable to fix our issues.

I think the scariest thing about death is trying and succeeding to rationalise it. The realistation that after you die, you essentially cease to exist (I could be wrong, perhaps the afterlife is real) and everything that has happened up to that point did not matter, nor will anything that will happen after that point matter. And so, why should you still be alive? Why not just die now? I think this poses the question of "Should I live?". At least to me, this is the scariest question mortality poses, and I actively try not to rationalise it, afraid I will come to this conclusion and end my life. Otherwise I am not afraid of death, and have never thought of immortality as a good thing, nor do I wish to live long enough to "update myself into the cloud". On the contrary, I see death as a relief, but I don't want to want to seek it actively.

I think, if EVERYBODY is immortal, we will have to stop having children, or at least have them at a severely decreased rate. That, in itself, isn't a bad thing necessarily, but what that means is that the world is unlikely to change. The greatest changes happen when new generations come of age .You'll find that lots of old people are set in their ways, whilst young people are maybe a bit more liberal in their ideas. If the same people who kidnapped and sold people as slaves were alive today, do you think we'd be seeing a decrease in racism? If there were only our grandparents in the world, staying forever young, would we be seeing gay rights? Life and death are a cycle that moves the world forward, if you cut part of that out, the cycle cannot continue. But to have a small minority of immortals, it wouldn't do much harm.

Am I the only one who got really annoyed with that Alcor guy for comparing death- a natural process that EVERY LIVING ORGANISM goes through- to smallpox or slavery? This is sorta controversial, but in my opinion, it's only ethical to try to expand someone's lifespan if they're still alive. If they die, that should be that. Curing smallpox was something done to already living patients, and slavery is a social evil that's entirely man-made. I can recognize the fact that Alcor has good intentions, but I felt like everything the CEO was saying felt wrong. Plus, the ability for people to be revived for a high price would definitely create a class divide, but I'm not going to get into that.

Yeah, Michael's decision is basically the decision I made a couple years ago, though I haven't committed to it in writing just yet. I want to live for as long as I can, and to die when the time comes that I can't. I would rather have had a short, meaningful life, than spend most of eternity in some vegetative state. And when my time does come, I want my body to be returned to the earth: no embalming, no cold steel casket, just a marker on the ground saying where I was laid to rest, and maybe a wooden box that will decay alongside me.


That said, however, I do still believe in an afterlife, so maybe I'm not as prepared to die as I say I am. And while being dead doesn't scare me, the actual process of dying doesn't sound like it's going to be pleasant. Still, there's nothing I can do to prevent it, so I guess I'm just going to have to deal with that when the time comes.

One issue I've always considered about immortality is how people's emotions tend to change as they live longer, which (to my knowledge) we have thus far been unable to link to mental decline and so could well be experiential in nature.
Some people find as they age that they feel a greater degree of satisfaction in life, they are happier with simpler things.
Others actually experience the exact opposite, noting higher rates of depression as they age.
Other still find that they actually become somewhat numb as they grow old, they feel less extreme lows but also less extreme highs.

So what if we image this trend were to continue as an immortal, and take them logical conclusion.
Well, eventually the first group might find themselves practically euphoric while doing nothing, meaning they'd have no reason to ever do anything, and would likely opt to just sit in a chair somewhere forever (which is somewhat ironic, as often the reason people give for wanting to live forever is to continue experiencing).
The second group might spiral into misery, living a tortured existence with emotional pain that grows worse and worse, almost certainly leading to their suicide if possible, or to an allegory for hell if not, where they will suffer immeasurably for eternity.
The final group, well, they might simply become literal psychopaths, their emotions dampening until they feel nothing at all.

I think that if another experiment were run similar to this, it would be worth adding a third group which you treat similarly to the group answering the initial questionnaire. Instead, however, they answer a questionnaire similar in length, but about a completely unrelated topic to death. Similarly, to maintain consistency, place unassuming posters around the room inside which they're (the third group) answering the questions. Then test their average response time and score to the 1-7 questions. A possibility which could be skewing the 1-7 response times would be perhaps after writing a lengthy response to a questionnaire, this has resulted in them being mentally tired, and unable to think as quickly since they've just expended mental energy with the previous response. I feel this wasn't touched on as a possibility in the episode, and personally I find myself taking longer to answer simple questions after writing extensively, particularly about heavy topics.

To me, death is essentially just a social construct. We're expected to die, we've always been told that we'll die, and we're told that there will be a day when we too must accept death. But why? I have life, and that is something so extraordinary and unusual that giving it up without a fight just seems ludicrous. The universe doesn't intend to destroy life any more than it intended to create it; both are merely accidents that were decided by little more than an enormous game of chance. Nothing dictates that we should die any more than anything dictates that we should be alive, so why shouldn't I fight to be alive?

I want to watch this world as it develops into something far beyond what I could possibly imagine at this current moment in time, and if that future is bleaker than I imagine it to be then I want to be there to fight against what I believe is wrong so that I can help create the future that I so strongly believe. I want to help build a future where everyone can be happy and humanity can thrive at an unprecedented level. It feels almost immoral for me to die. It's accepting defeat over the fate of the world and saying "what happens from here on out is not my responsibility." I believe that I personally can contribute towards making the world a better place just like anyone else can, and I'll either surpass death or die trying.

Yes, thats what science is about: design an experiment for one question and answer another a posteriori question with it.

In demo 1 michael and co, considering TMT, predicted that the salience of the mortality-reminding stimuli would produce a higher average punishment rating (1-7) but this is not necessarily a good prediction... rather it should predict not a higher average but more polarisation (more 1,2s and 6,7s and less 3,4,5s) as this is more representative of decisions being dictated by a stronger allegiance to ones world views(granted these worldviews were diverse in the sample)!!! Further, the effect for the experimental group is moderated by the worldview of the respective participants... if all their (the experimental group) worldviews were conducive to lighter punishments, then a lesser average should be predicted... if all their worldviews were conducive to heavier punishments then a higher average should be predicted! Who is with me here?

Accepting death is weakness.


Just because death is prevalent in our lives and has been a major event for humans throughout our history, it doesn't mean we have to accept it. Using excuses like "it's inevitable", "that's natural" and even philosophical rhetoric "what is life but meaningless without death" exemplifies the cowardice towards death, which is socially ingrained into us.


We do not have to lower our guns and surrender to death. You can:
1. Be a researcher and try to cure aging;
2. Learn robotics and try to transport yourself into a robot;
3. Be a programmer and try to transport yourself into a computer;
4. Be a doctor and try to extend your life;


These are a few examples of career choices which you can make a move against death today. And it is not complete science fiction. Robotics and prosthetics are promising fields and, in regards to curing aging, there are animals that do not age as well as supplements (current in test phase on mice) that can possibly extend our lives by decades. Aging is a disease and death goes against our biological role in life.

People who are completely unhinged from reality and believe they are immortal gods have a more liberal view of crime and justice.

Not fear of death, fear of having contributed nothing after death.

Isaac Asimov had an interesting take on this question. For him, death for everyone is essential to the betterment of humanity. According to him, as we age, our beliefs and ideas become ossified and almost permanent. We become more stubborn and slow to change our ways. If you happen to be one who holds a sizable sphere of influence in the world and never die, it would translate to a very slow cultural change as new ideas are probably going to meet with more resistance than if the holders of old ideas died. To him, change is an important ingredient in moving forward culturally. If people were never to die, change would be drawn to a crawl if not ultimately stunted.

@vsauce @Michael I was thinking about the Cryopreservation of the clinically dead patients/bodies: Let's assume that the technology has developed after 200 years, you/your memories are active, I think of the following:
1. It is cool to see technology and the planet. What next? You probably are not smart than the people around you...Maybe you hate to be back after a couple of time.
2. What if, only the cryo-technology has been developed but rest of Earth's eco-system is destroyed? If the people live in a life pod, can you digest?
3. Do normal people accept you in the community? Maybe there are already a lot of people on Earth and the world does not want people from the past to be active. Politics/people might stop the cryo-companies to get people back. Exception: If we can terraform Mars or go explore more galaxies and find new Earth/s.
4. You have memories 200 years old but you don't know anyone around you to share your feelings. Even your great-great grandkids don't know/recognise you. Worst case they are not interested at all.

What do you think? The above points are just my personal views. It is not intended to point out anyone. Thanks for reading :)

I agree with the mortician. The idea that life is going to continue on as we know and love it, yet somehow everyone will live forever: that's just not sensible. And, it not only denies the end state of death itself, but the whole life cycle of a human. Should a person live as an 8 year old for 1000 years? Should a person have 8000 children over the course of centuries? If there is no aging and no death, what kind of life would people live? There would be no progression. What we think of as societal values now would have to change dramatically. And, it would only be a matter of aging. If you slip off of a cliff, you're still going to die. So, from accidents, to illness, to homicide, how long could a person last anyway even if they didn't age?

I truly appreciate Michael in the sense that (and many other ways) he always chooses his annunciation and sentence structuring to be inoffensive and open-minded to all possible opinions on a specific topic, whether or not he agrees to it. That truly takes an immense amount of maturity and intelligence.

To be, or not to be, that is the question:
Whether 'tis nobler in the mind to suffer
The slings and arrows of outrageous fortune,
Or to take arms against a sea of troubles
And by opposing end them. To die—to sleep,
No more; and by a sleep to say we end
The heart-ache and the thousand natural shocks
That flesh is heir to: 'tis a consummation
Devoutly to be wish'd. To die, to sleep;
To sleep, perchance to dream—ay, there's the rub:
For in that sleep of death what dreams may come,
When we have shuffled off this mortal coil,
Must give us pause—there's the respect
That makes calamity of so long life.
For who would bear the whips and scorns of time,
Th'oppressor's wrong, the proud man's contumely,
The pangs of dispriz'd love, the law's delay,
The insolence of office, and the spurns
That patient merit of th'unworthy takes,
When he himself might his quietus make
With a bare bodkin? Who would fardels bear,
To grunt and sweat under a weary life,
But that the dread of something after death,
The undiscovere'd country, from whose bourn
No traveller returns, puzzles the will,
And makes us rather bear those ills we have
Than fly to others that we know not of?
Thus conscience does make cowards of us all,
And thus the native hue of resolution
Is sicklied o'er with the pale cast of thought,
And enterprises of great pitch and moment
With this regard their currents turn awry
And lose the name of action.

Several reasons why it would be worth living forever: 1. A person eventually gains experience, enriches himself intellectually, becomes wiser, and this means he is getting better. The longer we live, the better the society as a whole becomes. 2. A person does not have enough 70 years of life to realize himself creatively in many forms in which he would like. Eternal life gives him this opportunity. 3. Not everyone succeeds in seeing their offspring two generations in advance. But what if you live so long that you can pass on your experience to your great-great-great-great-grandchildren? 4. Centenarians - carriers of real history. Think about how historical science would develop if we had witnesses to the history that happened 200, 300, 400 years ago? There are other reasons to live forever. The apology of death is self-deception and an excuse from powerlessness to oppose something to it. Death is a form of universal violence, an absolute evil. It should not be.


Несколько причин, по которым стоило бы жить вечно: 1. Человек со временем набирается опыта, обогащается интеллектуально, мудреет, а это значит становится лучше. Чем дольше мы живем, тем лучше становится общество в целом. 2. Человеку не хватает 70 лет жизни реализовать себя творчески во многих ипостасях, в которых хотелось бы. Вечная жизнь дает ему эту возможность. 3. Далеко не каждому удается увидеть своих отпрысков на два поколения вперед. А что, если ты живешь столько, что можешь передать свой опыт своим пра-пра-пра-пра внукам? 4. Долгожители - носители реальной истории. As much as I (and most others) think that an extended lifespan would be beneficial, it is unintentionally selfish to consider that you, as a person, should live longer than what's expected. Annoyingly, we can only regret the things we didn't do in hindsight, which is how regret works. We only tend to yearn to do things that we haven't had time to do until its too late, so it's important to imagine yourself moments from death, thinking about all those times you wasted opportunities simply because you've told yourself, "There'll be another time to do that". Imagine the overwhelming urges you'll feel once it's too late, and pull them from the future and into your present mind and body. I think the most important thing is to be able to lay on your death bed, satisfied that you lived a fulfilling, meaningful and happy life, and the ability to leave behind a legacy for others to continue, whether that be art, knowledge or a loving family that will miss you dearly. Yes, without little consideration, I would like to live forever, but I shouldn't. Who am I to live longer than the person next to me? We all get that little blip of existence, so make the most of it <3

I’m really on the fence about immortality. On face value, it sounds great. It appeals to your animal survival instinct in a way that no other concept can touch. But time runs long...especially human perception of time. Not only that but the fleeting nature of life is part of what gives it its meaning. The thing that REALLY turned me around on immortality was Kevin Smith’s near death experience. He describes a feeling of ultimate completion and satisfaction. Like you’ve passed the ultimate test and can finally relax for real because the burden of your responsibilities has finally been lifted after all these years. That made a lot of sense to me. I’ve always tried to see death as just something that accompanies life. Death is NECESSARY for life. It’s not a bad thing and the fact that we got to have a run at this world, becoming part of the universe being made aware of itself is unbelievable. Even just 5 minutes of life is a mind blowing concept. A century and enough time to take in a human lifetime’s worth of experience is more than any collection of molecules could ever ask for. Eternal life? Meh...I could take it or leave it at this point.

I have been thinking about these sort of questions in this video for the last several years. If we could live forever, should we? Would it cause problems with overpopulation and the environment we live in. If there was a way to live forever that was discovered, would it be hidden from the general public to protect us from the problems it would cause. I have also thought of the idea that if we could live forever, what could be done to prevent the problems that come with it. I have thought of ideas like maybe you should have the ability to reproduce or have children if you are to make the choice to live forever. I have also thought of things like how the idea of reincarnation after death and keeping our memories would be a good way for this to work, but I don’t think that reincarnation is real. If the opportunity came, I would definitely choose live forever, but what could that do to this world, the people around us, or even the universe if everybody could live forever and choose to? I have sat there in thought and debated with myself for many hours about this.

This is a really interesting topic. Many of us won't randomly out of nowhere think of death unless we or someone around us is faced with it. A question I have is: Do we understand the complexities of life (specifically conscious life) enough to be able to make the "correct" decision for our own mortality? This isn't a question specifically with an afterlife in mind, but the source of life as well. We have had opinions on what happens after death for centuries, but we don't often think about what goes into creating and maintaining the most basic aspects of life down to even lower than cellular organelles. Can we truly make a decision about life before we know how it's made?

Total waste of time. The question asked in the beginning is should I die. The key operator is the word I, not “them”or “somebody else”. Instead the opening question is followed by a quiz administered to mostly younger people with the quiz questions that have nothing to do with “should I die” but rather “how should I punish someone who committed some type of a crime, death penalty not a choice”. Next we hear opinions from a mortician, definitely still in her prime age, followed by a founder of company who sells body freezing services. Not a single person is age 70 plus as far as I could see, nobody is asked directly about their own mortality and how they feel about it. Pseudoscience. Waste of time.

Our position about our own death evolves as we go through life. It is driven partially about how we feel about our own mission toward self and others (completed or not). Illnesses and pain, both mental and physical do have huge influence about how we see death. Feeling of loneliness, abandonment, lack of purpose are also contributing factors. Nothing of that is covered in this video. The title is completely misleading. Again, waste of time.

Hello Michael,

First of all thank you for you video, I enjoyed it, as always.
But I would like to share a few thoughts about how your experiment was designed, because I think it could be improved.
I don't know what budget did you have for it, so perhaps you already knew all that I'm going to say but anyways...

So first of all, your sample is really small, I think in order to have a more significant average sum at the end, you need way more participants, like a minimum of a 100 people, in order to not have extremes influence the average by this much (like for example that one woman who almost always had chosen 1) with more participants, the average is more accurate.

Secondly, the choice between 1 and 7 is wrong, it doesn't allow people to freely choose a number of years in sentence that represent their raw feeling and also, exclude the possibility to have a minimum and maximum sentence per group. In both cases there were 1s and 7s what if you let people choose a number of years / months freely, and / or also letting them choose the death sentence and no-sentence option. Perhaps we could see if one group has no death-sentences, and the other does? What if one group has a no-sentence and the other don't? This could be interesting to see.
As an example, if I want to choose a life in prison sentence, and you want only 10 years in prison, you both choose 7 because it's the highest number.
Just like that woman did, she picked 10 and counted it like a 7, were clearly she wanted way more than the other woman that also picked 7. Both 7s are not equal.

Anyways, the episode was great and very interesting, and I'm looking forward for all other episodes !

I didn’t like the experiment I thought it was unethical.






Not because of the experimental group but I thought that the professors were unprofessional. As a psych major they teach you a lot about confirmation bias in psychological research. One of the first things the researcher said was “well what were hoping for is X” which is a major red flag in the psychological sciences. The attitude you need to have when conducting these procedures is not “well I’m theorizing x and y will PROVE X CORRECT, so I should look for y”
That’s confirmation bias and it will lead to misleading or inaccurate results. What you should instead think is “I’m theorizing x and z will DISPOVE x, so I should look for z”

Also there were things in the experiment that weren’t controlled and made the research sloppy at best. For instance in the experimental group, the age difference between them and the control was too wide. So the ppl that weren’t asked about their death were on the younger side and the ppl that were were mostly older, with one of them having gray hair. This will obviously lead to misleading results for a number of reasons but one of them being the fact that the hypothesis is saying that people IN GENERAL are afraid of change because they are afraid of death. Not that people of a certain age are. So it’s important to control for things like age because the prospect of death for a younger person is not as pressing and prevelant and therefore is not as scary to a younger person as it is for someone who is older and death is a much more imminent possibility.
I don’t know if any of this was done or purpose to be manipulative or if these people simply didn’t do their homework in their undergrad or in grad school but I find the latter to be highly unlikely due to the fact that grades are a very important factor to anyone who wishes to go into research and since this is show business, a betting person would say that this was likely not coincidental or accidental. But either way not the most ethical way to conduct a study especially if it’s being recorded to “prove” it’s theory.

I'm really not happy with the conclusions of this episode...

Children still learn, build and create sometimes with more passion than any adult and this normally completely without being threatened or even aware that they will die in like 80 years.
Even more so, a lot of people fall into depression when they find out that they have a deadly disease. Despite having less time to leave a mark in history than they previously thought.
I'd even go so far to say, that a lot of people are willing to ignore stuff because they won't be alive to experience the full extend of the consequences of their doing.

We get bored after mere minutes of doing nothing to the point of rather inflicting pain to ourselves than to continue to do nothing. This can be countered by doing virtually nothing like watching TV but even this will get dull if you do this for a couple of days.

Micheal also probably had a schedule of when this season had to be finished, so no, he could not have done it 200 years later, if he had an indefinite lifespan. YouTube would have cancelled the show and probably sued his ass.

I'm not saying that the inevitability of death has no influence whatsoever, but saying that the impending doom is our only motivation seems a bit short sighted and ignores that it can just as well have a crippling effect on someone's motivation as it can support them.

A few years ago when I was 20, I accepted death. After having lived with depression for years, I walked from a party out in nowhere during winter. It was snowing and freezing. Eventually, I couldn't feel the cold anymore after having cried and wandered next to the road for hours, so I decided to just lay down in the snow, fall asleep, and eventually freeze to death. A strange good feeling of inner peace struck me as I was staring out into the endless space. The stars were so beautiful.

However, a friend of mine had been driving around to find me and he eventually did. He took me to his place, made me warm soup and put tons of blankets around me. I didn't die, but I honestly accepted the fact that I was going to die that night, I was so tired of living a life without meaning.

Just to note, I'm not suicidal anymore, and my depression has been cured through finding life-meanings. It's interesting, because after watching this episode, I feel more scared of death than I had previously been. I think it might be the thought that when my time comes, it might be a lot more uncomfortable than what I felt laying in the snow.

Edit: Also, it would have been interesting if Michael had interviewed people who had been or still are suicidal to hear their thought about death.

I don't really agree with the "no, if I was immortal I wouldn't want to do anything" idea.

We can't know for sure how we'd react because no one ever got an indefinitely long lifespan. We might (I'm 19) though. Who knows? Maybe my passion to do things will be just as strong because even if my time isn't limited, my brain is still the same brain, it can still be stimulated by the reward system. In this scenario, we would still feel the same emotions. Our thoughts may change, but our feelings are more directly controlled as a response to outside influence.

I don't understand her hatred of immortality. Accepting that I'll probably die and that some people will definately die and have died? I get that. I can understand that one. What's so wrong with hoping and genuinely believing that there's a non 0 chance of my life becoming indefinitely long? I'm not delusional. I know that it's not currently possible.

I do believe it'll be possible in the future, and I hope that it'll be possible in time for me.

I do want to make plans in case I can't live indefinitely, natural burial, no grave. Maybe cremation, although probably natural burial because why the hell not, if my brain can't be preserved (if it can then I'd go for that), then I won't need my body anymore because I won't exist.

I do want to live indefinitely if I can though. Hopefully I won't even need to go with cryo, because I'd rather not.
